post_body: What is the purpose of this scam?

comment.body:
The scam is:
1. You say yes when they ask you, they go with you to look for it
2. They don‚Äôt have the exact one he needs. But he says they probably do in another shop. You said you would help him, so he tries to get you to go to the other shop.
3. You don‚Äôt want to go to the other shop but you feel bad because you already said yes to help
4. He helpfully suggests you take out cash and give it to him and he‚Äôll go to the other shop. 
5. You end up giving him 1-200kr in cash thst you wouldn‚Äôt have considered otherwise
Yes that's a scam. Not sure what the purpose is, might be for resale, but it's certainly a scam.

The purpose is not to get the baby formula. They want money.  This is an old scam, sometimes they include their children too.

They want to gain the empathy of the people by asking for the formula first.  When they buy it for them and hand it to them, they will engage in a conversation and start sharing how desperate and terrible their situation is.

The formula is only the catch, they usually target women and old people. If someone is willing to buy the formula they know they are likely to give them money too.

That's why he said it is not the good formula, he wanted to manipulate you into giving him money instead of going back to the store. That's why he said that nonsense about the expiry date, but then he felt like he can't scam you so he just moved on to the next person.
Don't contribute to it thanks

Oh man.. I just realized I fell for that scam a few years ago.  
The specific baby powder wasn't there, and there was an ATM just a few meters away from the store..

There are several steps that follow, depending on how willing and easy a target you are. The next step is asking for cash, alternatively a loan of 200-400 DKK, either in cash. Typically, you‚Äôre very close to an ATM. The next step is asking for your phone number so they can supposedly repay you via MobilePay. However, that never happens. Instead, the scammer will call you later, claiming to be in a desperate situation and needing to borrow more money. The same scam is common near gas stations, where they claim to need cash for fuel or a bus ticket. When they‚Äôre most aggressive, they‚Äôll step in front of a cyclist, blocking your way so you can‚Äôt move on until you talk to them.
